{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559937,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T00:19:37.266Z","cooked":"

Hey, CD.

Our team is having some difficulties getting our elevator to perform as well as it theoretically can. Specifically, we have been needing to tune it slower on the up motion as when it comes down it is too violent. I have seen references to using a Kg factor in WPILib’s profiled PID controller used here by 3255, but there doesn’t seem to be a similar function in REV’s implementation of PID controllers.

Is there a way we can help account for gravity on our elevator using the REV library? Are we forced to run the PID on the RIO and then just set the outputs to the sparks rather than run the control loop on the Spark Max?

Our code is here for reference.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T00:19:37.266Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":50,"reads":207,"readers_count":206,"score":291.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/FRCTeam272/LC2025-Havelock/tree/main","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5},{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/brushless/revlib/closed-loop-control-overview/smart-motion","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Smart Motion Control | REV ION Brushless","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-3255-supernurds-2025-build-thread/477499/116","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 3255 SuperNURDs - 2025 Build Thread","clicks":3},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/profiled-pidcontroller.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Combining Motion Profiling and PID Control with ProfiledPIDController — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559982,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T00:58:25.924Z","cooked":"

We use MaxMotion with our elevator.

To tune it I set up a project where I could input Max Velocity, Max Acceleration, P, D and an arbitrary feed forward value on the dashboard so I could change on the fly.

Also on the dash I could set my MaxMotion set point.

Started with very low vel and acc values. Like 200, 200 and nothing in the P and D

Set a set point and as expected the elevator did nothing. I also monitor the elevator motor applied voltage so I can see what voltage the Max Motion controller was commanding.

Then I just gently increased the P until I started to get movement to the set point.

Kept increasing the P until the elevator could achieve the max velocity value and hit the setpoint with minimal overshoot.

Then started increasing the velocity and acceleration and adjusting the P until the elevator operated at an acceptable speed. Just use the D to help with any over shoot to the set point.

Now, when doing all this I would get jitter on the elevator when it reached the set point.

So, once I was satisfied with P,D, acc and vel I put the elevator at a set point then started increasing the arbitrary feed forward value until the jitter disappeared at any setpoint.
Was also monitoring the current draw on the elevator motor as well to fine tune the arbitrary ff value to a point that stopped the jitter but minimized the current draw.

When returning the elector to the bottom that is an edge case where I set the arbitrary ff to 0

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T00:58:25.924Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"AfterTen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560019,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T01:26:33.980Z","cooked":"

We have a general understanding on how to tune PID, as you described, but we still have issues with down being sooooo much faster and more violent than up. Is the rev KFF value similar in functionality to the Kg in the WPILib?

If so, can the KFF value be negative?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T01:26:33.980Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":47.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":27113,"username":"AfterTen","name":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/3","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560028,"name":"Joshua J","username":"thatnameistaken","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T01:38:43.820Z","cooked":"

You don’t want to use the kF term (I think it’s just F in the REV API) for this; that linearly scales an output based on the setpoint.

Instead, use the overload of setReference() that includes the arbFeedForward argument. This stands for arbitrary feed forward, and simply adds whatever voltage you specify to the output calculated from the PID controller.

Edit: If you want a more refined feed forward that accounts for friction, velocity, and acceleration as well, use Oblarg’s suggestion below. But if you’re just trying to quickly implement a kG, adding arbFF to what you have will do that.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T01:41:58.338Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":160,"readers_count":159,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"Joshua J","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/spark/sparkclosedloopcontroller#setReference(double,com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.ControlType,com.revrobotics.spark.ClosedLoopSlot,double)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"SparkClosedLoopController (FRC-REVLib API)","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":10874,"username":"Cyberphil","name":"Phil Szymanowski","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19116,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CSA | Drive Coach (2191)"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560029,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T01:39:02.423Z","cooked":"

You should use TrapezoidProfile, ElevatorFeedforward, and Position PID mode on the spark max. Use the arbitrary feedforward parameter to pass in the output of the ElevatorFeedforward.

Thank you all for the help!

If I am understanding correctly, the TrapezoidProfile and ElevatorFeedforward method will run on the Rio side and feed a position value that the Spark Max Position PID attempts to follow?

Is there an example code of this for reference? It’s a bit difficult for us to understand exactly how each of these things work together.

I know the syntax is a bit different between Java and Python, but I think this should give us enough to work with.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T13:00:24.119Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":21.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"Phil Szymanowski","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58301,"username":"LHACK4142","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 272 (Cyber Crusaders), FTC 23598 (Robotic Pretzles)"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560577,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T14:48:47.907Z","cooked":"

We use the same setup, PID on a Spark Flex. We have had success with the arbitrary feed forward term, as already mentioned. I wanted to bring something else up. The D term can also help with slowing the elevator as it is going down. The D term acts in the opposite direction to the P and I terms, and is based on the rate of change of the error. In the case of elevator position control, the D term’s effect will be proportional to the elevator’s speed. If gravity is causing the elevator to approach its setpoint faster when going down and slower when going up, the D term’s counteracting effect will be greater when the elevator is going down and less when the elevator is going up.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T14:48:47.907Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":38.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560642,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T15:29:01.065Z","cooked":"

The acceleration portion of ElevatorFeedforward (a*kA) also has a similar effect, but isn’t susceptible to noise in measurements. In most cases, if kA is properly tuned and acceleration feedforward is used, it covers what D would do while the setpoint is moving. That said, D can function when the setpoint has reached the goal, whereas acceleration feedforward does nothing in that case.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T15:29:01.065Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":22.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495981,"topic_slug":"pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12266,"username":"John_Bottenberg","name":"John Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pid-control-of-elevator-with-rev-control-system-accounting-for-gravity/495981/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560695,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T16:12:00.211Z","cooked":"

Thanks to all for the help and clarifications! In our searching we couldn’t always find the definitions of all of the coefficients for the various control loops and don’t have a good understanding of when to use them and what their values should be.

For example, in the WPILib example here, there is a kP, kI, kD, kS, kG, and a kV. What is kS and kV? I assume kG is accounting for Gravity? kA is noted that it can be omitted, but why, and when is it useful? It seems to be related to the inertia of a system based on the blue box.

I see the notes about the units, but there is not much information about what each of these values means or represents.

It also looks like it uses a kDt input to the profiled PID controller, which I assume is some kind of acceleration constraint?

Cyberphil:

For example, in the WPILib example here, there is a kP, kI, kD, kS, kG, and a kV. What is kS and kV? I assume kG is accounting for Gravity? kA is noted that it can be omitted, but why, and when is it useful? It seems to be related to the inertia of a system based on the blue box.

Yeah, it takes some perusal to find where they are defined.

kS, kV, and kA come from DC motor feedforward. link 1 link 2

kG comes from the elevator feedforward; see link 1 above and this.

Regarding kDt, see the doc for the class; it is the argument “period”

It might not be the best solution to this problem, but my team had the same issue and decided to use two PID settings based on if we are going up or down. We put them in slots 0 and 1 so we could just reference those when adding the setpoint.

github.com

PerkValleyRobotics/2025RobotCode/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Elevator/ElevatorIOSparkMax.java#L121-L126


      
    
          
  1. public void setPosition(double position) {
    2. 
          
  2.     if (leftEncoder.getPosition() < position)
    3. 
          
  3.         controller.setReference(position, SparkBase.ControlType.kPosition, ClosedLoopSlot.kSlot0);
    4. 
          
  4.     else
    5. 
          
  5.         controller.setReference(position, SparkBase.ControlType.kPosition, ClosedLoopSlot.kSlot1);
    6. 
          
  6. }
    7.

VihaanC:

It might not be the best solution to this problem, but my team had the same issue and decided to use two PID settings based on if we are going up or down. We put them in slots 0 and 1 so we could just reference those when adding the setpoint.

This solution doesn’t really reflect the system dynamics and i would not recommend it.

I am no programmer but your problem with including the gravity, can be reduced or even eliminated IF you can make a small change in your elevator as seen in this post.

What do you think are the essentials for a very good elevator that is stable, fast and efficient? Technical
Well I am definitely not an expert in this topic but something Golden Horn (8159) use, are constant force springs which take away weight for the motors so they can have a ratio with less torque and more speed. And like that it’s faster. If I understood it correctly. Here’s the video from in which they also explain it a bit. [8159 Golden Horn | Behind the Bumpers | 2025 FRC REEFSCAPE Robot]

We have used CF springs many times before. Unfortunately, the design of our elevator this year makes implementing them quite difficult. We’re using two Swyft Ascends on either side of the robot, and the chain run that controls the up and down motion, where we would typically mount a CF spring, is shorter than the travel of the elevator.

Pic for reference:

PXL_20250316_1945536981920×2550 433 KB
